posts.name: Kal
posts.cooked:
This would be great feature that can be implement with schedule backup.
ex: backup every 30/60/90/180/etc and keep the most X number of backups. this way we can restore if ever needed

posts.cooked:
Hello!

would that be okay for you, if it is a simple backup in plain text?
Because to encrypt that in Google Drive and make it user-friendly is kinda difficult.

Kathy

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked: Signal backups on Android are encrypted before they are saved to external storage (Signal Settings > Chats and media > Chat backups).

Hello!

Spoilsport Of course I know that, I was looking forward to the answer, because I am sure 90% here do not care, whether a backup would be encrypted at all.

Kathy

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked: We would never implement plaintext cloud backup functionality

posts.name: Kal
posts.cooked: My point is not to make plain text backup you can still make the backup encrypted with the specific backup key and then set up a way to upload the backup to Google cloud or Mega or something like that.

I just use the file browser on my phone and upload the backup file.

I suppose it would be nice to have it automated but this isn’t a bad solution as is. You can manually move the file anywhere you like now.

Hello!

I think, this manual way is even better than an automatic one. Because backups are in general necessary, if something really important happens; thus, talking about Signal, very important messages arrive.
A regular backup plan can not handle that.

Kathy

posts.name: Kal
posts.cooked: I disagree if we have a time-based backup that we can control and also upload to the cloud there’s a higher chance of it not being lost if the phone was lost or destroyed or damaged by any chance. Correctly I know many apps that actually use Google services to login with and also to upload to Google Drive and make it all backed up.

Hello!

Well, maybe that depends alot on your personal use of your phone.
I have an iPhone, and sometimes I make an iTunes backup every 2 days, because so many things happen (I make new photos, buy new music, and so on), and sometimes really nothing spectacular happens for 2 weeks.
A regular backup plan, let’s say once a week, would be nonsense for me.

Kathy

kathy:

A regular backup plan, let’s say once a week, would be nonsense for me.

I’m impressed with your memory. :) I periodically always forget to make backups, so a scheduled backup would be great for me.

posts.name: Kal
posts.cooked: I wasn’t talking about backup weekly but let’s say 2,3,4,5,612,24 hours backup. Let’s assume something happens in between you backup and you’ll be SOL. Being a IT professional. Backups are important. Typically you have hourly then daily and weekly. You also have local and remote backup. This is on how much data are you willing to loose. In your case I guess you doing it manually hoping not to forget have 2 days worth of loss.
Can’t you just select Signal’s backup folder as “synchronized” with your cloud service?

Hello!

Well, it is not “hoping” not to forget. I just know when something important happened.
When I’m travelling, and nothing happens for a week, besides some private messages with friends or family, I don’t need backups.
When I work on something, and add tons of documents to my USB app, or obtain important messages, I just know, that when I come home I will make a backup first. Since I refuse Cloud services, I have to make a full iTunes backup everytime it is necessary.

It works, I’ve never lost any data so far.

Kathy

xyzzyx:

Can’t you just select Signal’s backup folder as “synchronized” with your cloud service?

That’s how I do Signal Backups on my NextCloud. Works fine.

link_counts.title: Back-up to Owncloud/Nextcloud server

posts.cooked:
Wopfi:

That’s how I do Signal Backups on my NextCloud. Works fine.

Thanks, I thought it was possible this way. Thus no reason to implement anything like this directly in Signal. Would only clutter the code and it’s impossible to support all cloud services.

posts.name: Samantha
posts.cooked: Hi, I’m new here– is there a way to export or back up conversations on the iPhone app? It seems like there’s a way to export to a plaintext file on the Android app, but not on the iPhone… has anyone found a work-around? I’d be happy to synch it to iTunes or my computer, too…

I would like to see Signal have an option to auto-upload the encrypted backup to a cloud storage provider of the user’s choice.

With a few of the encrypted messengers out there, as well as SMS, the majority of people have come to expect their chats will be saved somewhere and able to be restored in case they lose their phone or it gets stolen etc.

Most if not all of these backups are not encrypted, but Signal would of course go one better as its own backup is encrypted with a passphrase anyway. I believe that wouldn’t pose a privacy risk if it was then easy to have it automatically uploaded to e.g. Google Drive or OneDrive.

It might attract more users if they knew their chat history is secure and easy to backup/restore and that they wouldn’t lose it if anything happened to their phone.

This would need some design thinking of course, as the user would have to know and store their passphrase securely, so maybe it would not be enabled by default.

As far as I just read, google drive backups when using android pie will be encrypted, as long as the device is protected by a passcode.
This would mean, google would no longer have access to the backups. In this case, the situation would change a bit, I think.

posts.name: Karan
posts.cooked:
Currently bqlackup & restore technique is for advanced user ,
it is complicate to restore backup in when changing the device, we have to copy backup file in folder then restore.

Cloud backup feature is useful to restore & backup our data with passphrase,
